repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: no map to quickly see what highlights are applied to item under cursor
(A) Solution: map zS in normal mode, vim-scriptease style.

comment_data.body: If Inspect is documented you should reference it IMO. Also this risks duplication with the documentation for inspect.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4815,6 +4815,9 @@ You can see all the groups currently active with this command: >
     :so $VIMRUNTIME/syntax/hitest.vim
 This will open a new window containing all highlight group names, displayed
 in their own color.
+                                                        *zS-default*
+You can see a short summary of the the highlight groups applied to a given
+position using the keymapping `zS` in normal mode. |default-mappings|

comment_data.body:
nit/suggestion: shouldn't make a difference, but perhaps more idiomatic?

```suggestion
  vim.keymap.set('n', 'zS', vim.show_pos, { desc = ':help zS-default' })
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -65,6 +65,11 @@ do
     desc = ':help CTRL-L-default',
   })
 
+  --- https://github.com/tpope/vim-scriptease style mapping for `:Inspect`.
+  ---
+  --- See |zS-default|
+  vim.keymap.set('n', 'zS', '<Cmd>Inspect<CR>', { desc = ':help zS-default' })

comment_data.body: I've reworded it and included the link to `:Inspect`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4815,6 +4815,9 @@ You can see all the groups currently active with this command: >
     :so $VIMRUNTIME/syntax/hitest.vim
 This will open a new window containing all highlight group names, displayed
 in their own color.
+                                                        *zS-default*
+You can see a short summary of the the highlight groups applied to a given
+position using the keymapping `zS` in normal mode. |default-mappings|

comment_regular_data.body: I think we're starting to get a bit out of hand with all these new default keymaps. `:Inspect` already exists, do we _really_ need a default keymap for this?

> do we _really_ need a default keymap for this? 

There's no absolute need no, but it's not overriding a default binding, so I thought I'd put up this idea and gauge interest. I was at least hoping to gain a clearer picture of what can/can't/shouldn't be considered for default-mappings - maybe there's already a consensus somewhere that I missed when looking for it, in that case my apologies for wasting your time.

I'm in favor.

* `zS` is unused
* It makes a useful feature (a little) more accesible
* There's precedent from vim-scriptease (I've had the [same mapping configured for a long time](https://github.com/gpanders/dotfiles/blob/6663847837a3c4f8ccd3cf79f712966eaf9204b3/.config/nvim/init.vim#L97-L98))

Not sure what else we'd want to use `zS` for. I'd say we could even take this further and map `z<C-S>` to `:InspectTree` as well (`:InspectTree` is more annoying to enter manually since tab completion first completes `:Inspect`, so it requires a lot more key presses).

I'm against:
- `:Inspect` is already easy to execute.
- Listing highlights under the cursor is a debug thing, useful for nvim devs and plugins devs, which is very much who vim-scriptease is aimed at. 99% of users won't need this.
- A keymap being currently unused shouldn't be used to justify adding new mappings, that's already a requirement.

The `z` prefix is mostly used for fold and spelling functions, so unless there's a good reason, that it remains for that.

> just like they wonder where a mapping came from.

This directly implies that we need to add a mapping to find out where a mapping came from. I thought `:map ` was perfectly sufficient for that, just as `:Inspect` is sufficient for finding where highlights come from. Why does the general user need highly efficient access to either of these?

> Inspecting the editor will become more and more commonplace, especially with the mouse menu.

Adding this to the mouse menu sounds ok to me. I'm only objecting to a built in keymap.

> Adding this to the mouse menu sounds ok to me. I'm only objecting to a built in keymap.

Mainly to put the idea in their head. I suppose we could just mention the mapping at `:help :Inspect` instead. Let's start with that.

:100: to what Lewis said and want to add that core using up more and more keymaps by default also makes it harder for plugins to use or recommend mappings.

keymaps are a finite resource which imho should be reserved for actions that are common and frequently used - that's also where they excel due to memorization aspect. Troubleshooting is not something you do all the time.

My most recent comment was a suggestion to only mention this as an example at `:help :Inspect`:

    vim.keymap.set('n', 'zS', vim.show_pos)

So we won't define the mapping, but just give a nudge. The nudge covers most of the benefit of the default mapping without raising questions about whether it's justified.

> My most recent comment was a suggestion to only mention this as an example at :help :Inspect:

Ah I misunderstood your comment. This sounds fine to me.

Anecdotally, I've had a similar mapping mapped to `<leader>z` for over a decade that's evolved over time, but since `:Inspect` was introduced, I don't find myself using it anymore, mostly because I forget about it. The only time I've found the mapping particularly useful was when developing vimscript syntax and indent files, and more recently developing treesitter queries. Other than that, I now mostly use `:Inspect` for checking semantic highlights.

title: feat(defaults): zS triggers Inspect command
